stem: Dr. {{candidate_name}}, you are planning a spinal anaesthetic for a 70-year-old woman having a total hip replacement. Talk me through your approach.

prompts.text: What are the indications and contraindications for spinal anaesthesia?
expectedKeyFacts: Indications: lower limb, pelvic, lower abdominal surgery; obstetric procedures
Advantages: avoids general anaesthesia, excellent analgesia, reduced DVT risk
Absolute contraindications: patient refusal, infection at injection site, coagulopathy, severe hypovolaemia
Relative contraindications: fixed cardiac output states (severe AS), raised ICP, sepsis, previous spinal surgery
Check platelets >80×10⁹/L, INR <1.4, stopped anticoagulation appropriately
LMWH: stop prophylactic dose 12 hours, therapeutic dose 24 hours before

prompts.text: Describe your technique for performing a spinal anaesthetic.
expectedKeyFacts: Position: sitting or lateral, flexed spine
Identify level: Tuffier's line (iliac crests) = L4/L5
Aseptic technique: gown, gloves, mask, chlorhexidine prep, sterile drape
Infiltrate local anaesthetic subcutaneously
Insert spinal needle (25G pencil-point) at L3/L4 or L4/L5
Advance through: skin, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, epidural space, dura
Confirm CSF flow, inject local anaesthetic slowly
Typical dose: 2-3 mL heavy bupivacaine 0.5% (10-15 mg)
Assess block height with cold or pinprick

prompts.text: What are the potential complications of spinal anaesthesia?
expectedKeyFacts: Hypotension: most common, due to sympathetic blockade and vasodilation
Post-dural puncture headache: <1% with pencil-point needles
Bradycardia: Bezold-Jarisch reflex, high block affecting cardiac sympathetics
Total spinal: inadvertent high block, respiratory compromise, loss of consciousness
Neurological injury: rare, direct trauma or ischaemia
Cauda equina syndrome, spinal haematoma (very rare)
Urinary retention
Back pain at injection site

prompts.text: How would you manage severe hypotension after spinal anaesthesia?
expectedKeyFacts: Prevention: IV fluid preload 500 mL, avoid aortocaval compression (left lateral tilt)
Treatment: fluid boluses 250-500 mL crystalloid
Vasopressor: phenylephrine 50-100 mcg or metaraminol 0.5-1 mg
Ephedrine 6-9 mg if bradycardic
Increase oxygen delivery
Raise legs if possible
Severe/refractory: consider small dose adrenaline, exclude high block
Monitor: frequent BP, assess block height, check consciousness

rescuePrompt: Perhaps you could tell me about the surface anatomy for spinal anaesthesia — how do you identify the correct level?
keyFacts: Indications: lower limb, pelvic, lower abdominal surgery
Layers: skin, supraspinous, interspinous, ligamentum flavum, epidural, dura
Complications: hypotension, PDPH, bradycardia, total spinal

scoringGuidance.pass: Lists indications and contraindications including coagulopathy, describes technique with correct anatomy and aseptic precautions, knows complications and their management especially hypotension, appropriate vasopressor choice; stronger candidates discuss anticoagulation timing and prevention strategies
scoringGuidance.borderline: Knows spinal is for lower body surgery but indications/contraindications incomplete, technique described but anatomy vague, mentions hypotension but management unclear
scoringGuidance.fail: Cannot describe indications or contraindications, does not know surface anatomy, technique unsafe or incomplete, unaware of major complications or their management
